0.text:
Hello everybody Claudia Boleyn here. This
was originally going to be a depression question

4.text:
and answer session about depression and mental
health and all that kind of thing but I've

8.text:
had so many asks, so many questions that there
was no way I'd be able to pack them into one

13.text:
video. So I've decided to do a series of videos
answering the questions and I've kind of split

19.text:
them into different categories so today's
vlog is going to be, well today's question

24.text:
and answer session is going to be specifically
about self harm.

28.text:
I should also warn you that I'm probably going
to cry my make up off in this video at some

32.text:
point so don't worry about me if I get upset
it's obviously just a really personal topic

37.text:
and I think it's quite natural to get upset
about it so please don't worry about me.

41.text:
All the questions in today's video are anonymous
questions which I can totally understand.

46.text:
There's a huge stigma against people who self
harm and I can totally see why you might not

50.text:
want to put your name to these questions so
that's absolutely fine. I've chosen the questions

54.text:
which I think I can answer the best and which
I think might be helpful as well so I hope

60.text:
that this video is helpful to you in some
way.

62.text:
Question number one is: When Did You Start
Self Harming And Why?

66.text:
Um, I was about twelve when I started. I didn't
know what self harming was. I used to scratch

71.text:
my thumbs with safety pins when I was really
upset and stressed and angry. I also used

77.text:
to starve myself so I used to restrict my
food intake and I would go for about three

81.text:
days without eating until I thought I was
going to pass out. And obviously looking back

85.text:
now I can see that that is a self harming
behaviour. My aim wasn't to lose weight or

90.text:
anything, it wasn't anorexia or anything like
that, although I have got some symptoms of

95.text:
eating disorders. It's a bit complicated but
it was a sort of self-punishment so for me

100.text:
that goes under the self harm umbrella.
I think I used to restrict food because the

106.text:
feeling you'd get when you didn't eat for
three days was… you'd be lightheaded and

110.text:
you felt sick and you felt cold and incredibly
hungry and you were just in a lot of pain

116.text:
you'd get aches and pains everywhere and it
was a horrible feeling but it used to distract

120.text:
me from the other feelings that I had and
for me that was a relief because the feelings

124.text:
I was having inside my head were just too
much to cope with so it was a relief for me

129.text:
to have a physical kind of pain that I could
go to instead so I didn't have to think about

135.text:
the way I was feeling.
As for the second part of that question, why

139.text:
did I self harm or why do I? um I've decided
not to talk about why for a number of reasons

144.text:
but I can say that it was because I felt and
feel a lot of anger inside me that I don't

153.text:
feel like I'm able to express and I wasn't
able to express when I was younger. It's a

159.text:
very difficult situation and I feel very trapped
and it's a very unique situation. I know I'm

166.text:
not the only one in the world with it, but
it's a complicated one which is too difficult

170.text:
to explain and also I love the people involved
very much so it's difficult for me to talk

179.text:
about. So that's why I'm not going to talk
about exactly why.

182.text:
Question number two is: What Did Your Parents
Do When They Found Out And How Did You Tell

186.text:
Them?
I want to preface this answer by saying that

190.text:
I am telling you this out of love for you
so that you can know that you're not alone

197.text:
if you've had a similar experience to me.
I don't say this out of spite, I love both

202.text:
my parents a lot and I'm really sorry if I
get a bit upset talking about this because

209.text:
it's still very raw for me and I think you
might understand why when I tell you about

215.text:
it.
I didn't tell my mum about the self harm but

217.text:
she found out because the school rang her.
My school rang her. One of my best friends

223.text:
told a teacher that she was worried about
me and, you know what, I really love her for

229.text:
doing that. There was no way she could have
understood my home situation properly because

234.text:
I never spoke about it in detail so she thought
she was doing what was right and the fact

240.text:
that she went to someone because she was so
worried about me, you know, she must have

243.text:
agonised about that, I really value her so
much for that. I'm not in contact with her

247.text:
that much anymore, but you know, she'll always
mean a lot to me because she really cared

251.text:
about me and she tried to help. But anyway
the school rang my mum because they knew I

258.text:
was cutting my arms and I wasn't eating and
I was depressed and potentially going through

263.text:
a breakdown. I was, I didn't know that at
the time. And they didn't know about the family

268.text:
situation obviously, which probably would
have helped cause they wouldn't have rung

272.text:
home if they'd known about that, but they
did ring home, there's no way I can stop that

277.text:
now, it's happened. When my mum found out
about it she actually tried to kick me out

283.text:
of the house so she told me she didn't want
me living under her roof anymore, that I was

290.text:
selfish, manipulative, and twisted, and she
didn't want me under her roof and that I should

297.text:
just go. So, that was very upsetting. Luckily
my grandma was there at the time, my Grandma

307.text:
seems to always be there when these big family
things happen and she sat with me and I, I

312.text:
remember my mum sitting across from me with
my brother, I think my brother was there,

317.text:
she was on the sofa across from my grandma
and I just remember her snarling at me and

323.text:
shouting at me and just, I don't know, I just
felt like the smallest most worthless person

329.text:
in the world. I just, I felt dreadful and
just thinking about it makes me feel really

334.text:
bad. But luckily my grandma persuaded her
to let me stay and she calmed her down a little

340.text:
bit. She stuck up for me. I just remember
my grandma hugging me the whole time, it was

343.text:
like she was trying to shield me from the
words. That's a really emotional memory for

349.text:
me. So sad.
I think that my mum was angry because she…

357.text:
because I'd been hiding it from her as well
and… the thing is I'd hidden it from her

363.text:
and my brother because I didn't want to upset
them with it, you know? I was very, I was

368.text:
in a really bad place, and I didn't want to
trouble…t mean no-one was listening, at

373.text:
that time nobody was there to listen to me
anyway and I didn't have anybody I could turn

377.text:
to at all. I was completely alone but I was
determined I wasn't going to go to my little

382.text:
brother because obviously he's younger than
me and I didn't want to put any extra stress

386.text:
on him, and I couldn't go to my mum or lots
of reasons. Um, and so I did it in secret…

396.text:
but somehow that got twisted into me being
manipulative and… i don't know, it was just

402.text:
the most awful situation and I just still
think about it all the time and I don't think

408.text:
I'll ever forgive my mum for that really.
I love her, a lot, and I really hope she wouldn't

413.text:
mind me making this video but I think it's
important because I want other parents to

418.text:
know, other mothers especially to know that
if your child comes to you and your child

423.text:
is self harming and they're depressed, then
they haven't done it to hurt you or to manipulate

429.text:
you, like what they want is they want you
to just give them a hug and tell them it's

434.text:
gonna be alright. Please don't scream at them,
please, cause if you're self harming then

439.text:
you're inwardly screaming at yourself all
the time, you hate yourself basically, and

445.text:
you don't want to make your kid feel as worthless
as I felt and still kind of do feel, so please

450.text:
don't do that.
My dad didn't find out about it until after

454.text:
I had attempted suicide. I had a very sporadic
relationship with my dad back then. Him and

462.text:
my mum divorced when I was three and a half
and at first I saw him quite a lot but then

466.text:
the contact just fizzled out, there was a
lot of arguing between my two families, well

471.text:
between my dad and my mum, and there were
a lot of issues there which I'm not going

475.text:
to go into in this video. And eventually it
just caused this massive wedge, and I stopped

479.text:
seeing my dad for years. I didn't see him
for such a long time, he just wasn't there

484.text:
anymore and I even grew to, like, to feel
really negatively towards him, I think because

492.text:
of the environment I grew up in. I think when
you come from a broken family that's kind

496.text:
of at war and you live with one side of that
family I think you absorb a lot of stuff that

501.text:
you don't mean to but you're a kid, so you
do. Luckily I've got rid of that now, so it's

505.text:
all better but… my dad was kind of just
back in my life at that point and my mum contacted

513.text:
him. My mum said to him, look, Claudy has
taken an overdose and she's been self harming

519.text:
and stuff, so I'm very worried about her.
And that's how my dad found out, so I didn't

523.text:
tell him and we've never really spoken about
it, really. My dad is like an optimistic person.

528.text:
He's like my driving force. So he'll ring
up and when I'm feeling bad he'll give me

531.text:
like little pep talks and he'll help me, you
know, plan my future and really get me going

536.text:
and get me motivated. So that's kind of the
way we connect over it, but I've never, we've

540.text:
never spoken about it other than him occasionally
saying, you know, you're not still doing that

545.text:
are you? And me answering no even if I am.
Yeah, so it's a lot easier with my dad but

551.text:
I haven't been able to talk about it to anybody
in my family.

556.text:
Question number three is: What Do You Do Instead
Of Self Harm Now?

559.text:
This is a really good question after the last
one cause the last one was a really sad one.

562.text:
Um, I haven't self harmed in two months. I
actually hadn't self harmed for about six

567.text:
months before that and then I had a little
relapse but that's okay, when you're in recovery

572.text:
you do relapse sometimes but now it's been
another two months or so so I'm doing really

577.text:
well. Um, so what do I do personally. I write
in a journal and I used to write on big sheets

583.text:
of paper. I bought this A3 really cheap pad
of paper and some coloured pens and for a

589.text:
while I used to, when I was feeling really
bad, I would just go in my bedroom and shut

593.text:
the door and just scribble on them. So I'd
be writing, like, swear words and names and

599.text:
drawing on it and just scribbling and writing
down what was making me angry and even just

605.text:
little petty things that had irritated me
in the say and I was just letting it all go

607.text:
and that really did used to help me but that
backfired because the one time my mum came

614.text:
in without knocking and she found me with
all the papers around me and she picked up

620.text:
the papers and read them all and she was just
really angry and disgusted and she threatened

626.text:
to take them to my brother. Um, yeah, that
was just really bad. So I don't do that anymore.

633.text:
Although it used to really help I don't do
that anymore. But writing about it does help

637.text:
you know, or getting it out somehow, because
right now I do it on my laptop so I just make

641.text:
a word document and just type what I'm feeling.
So that can help or if you have a journal

647.text:
that can really help. Yeah, writing on big
paper is a great idea if you've got a family

651.text:
who wouldn't mind you doing that.
A really good one is music. I have a playlist

655.text:
on my iPod which is just really loud angry
music and it helps me so much. I also have

661.text:
a Florence +the Machine playlist because I
just find that that music reminds me of who

667.text:
I am. Obviously that might not be Florence
+the Machine for you, but if you've got a

669.text:
band that you really connect to or something
then that can really help cause it reminds

673.text:
you of your kind of sense of self and who
you are, and it brings you back a bit. But

676.text:
that can be really helpful. I listen to it
really loudly in my ears, and that's probably

681.text:
not a healthy thing to do but it really helps
me because it drowns everything out and I

685.text:
can just lose myself in these songs and that
is just really helpful.

689.text:
In a specific type of self harm mood I go
to my Anne Boleyn book, my favourite Anne

694.text:
Boleyn book that I've got, and I just open
it at any page and just start reading. So

699.text:
that really helps me because Anne Boleyn is
a very inspirational force in my life and

703.text:
I've kind of used her as this kind of beacon
of hope and strength and when I think about

707.text:
her she makes me feel inspired and she makes
me want to be a stronger person and she makes

712.text:
me feel resilient and like I should keep fighting.
So that really really helps me so maybe if

718.text:
you've got a book that you really love or
a person that you really admire then you could

723.text:
look them up online or look at a picture of
them or something. Just something simple like

727.text:
that. I wish I could meet Anne just so I could
tell her, thank you. Cause the amount of times

732.text:
I've turned to her in a moment of real need
is just, it's really helped me, basically.

738.text:
Some actual alternatives to self harm which
I've tried are… there's the one where you

742.text:
ping an elastic band on your wrist. So you
put the elastic band on your wrist, when you're

745.text:
feeling angry instead of cutting your wrist
or cutting your arm, you would pull back the

750.text:
elastic band and ping it on your wrist and
it really hurts. It kind of feels all stingy

753.text:
and horrible. It doesn't actually help me,
that method, because for me something about

757.text:
seeing the blood and actually hurting myself
was part of why I did what I did. It was kind

762.text:
of a form of self-punishment in a way. But
I know that works for a lot of people, so

767.text:
don't discount it just because it didn't work
for me. Loads of people find real relief from

770.text:
that so that's something you can try.
Another one is holding an ice cube in your

774.text:
hand. Obviously when you hold the ice cube
in your hand it really kind of, it's really

778.text:
cold but it feels like it's burning. But that's
good because it's like a substitute for pain

781.text:
and it's not really going to actually hurt
you in the long run. I would do this but I

788.text:
can't because my family would notice if I
went to the freezer to get some ice, and I

793.text:
wouldn't want that. So. But if you have a
family which wouldn't mind then, you know,

798.text:
that's a really good idea cause I've done
it once before and it really helped me.

802.text:
The best method, in my opinion, is drawing
on your arms because where I wanted to make

807.text:
a mark with the knife now I just make a mark
with a coloured pen. I bought myself like

810.text:
a pack of coloured pens, like really cheap
coloured felt tips and when I feel like I

816.text:
want to cut I just write on my arms now and
I decorate them and I put stars and hearts

820.text:
and flowers and I write Anne's name and I
write other names and quotes on my arms and

825.text:
it's great because it distracts you and it
makes you feel that sense of self again, it

829.text:
draws you back. You're reminded of what's
important to you and it's just such a, it's

833.text:
a nice thing to do. And you feel really proud
when you wake up in the morning. My self harm

839.text:
urges usually happen at night, in the evening,
it's nice to wake up in the morning and see

844.text:
that you've drawn on your arm and you've made
something beautiful there instead of being

847.text:
destructive.
I actually took a couple of pictures of one

851.text:
that I did just because I felt so proud of
myself for getting past this particularly

855.text:
dark night. I might show you that. I think
I might put that on the screen for you. But

862.text:
I'm very proud of that.
Question number four is: What Makes A Person

867.text:
Self Harm?
I can't answer for everyone, obviously. Everyone

871.text:
has different reasons for doing it. I can
answer for me. I can talk about it vaguely,

879.text:
but again not in detail for a number of reasons.
There's a lot of reasons why I can't talk

884.text:
about it properly and I really would like
to but it's just not possible. So, I guess

892.text:
it's when I feel so much anger that I can't
express. It's when I feel injustice, like

897.text:
i'm being stifled, like I'm trapped and there's
no way of me safely expression that feeling…

904.text:
without making things worse. I don't get upset
in the slightest when people like anonymously

911.text:
send me hate mail and that kind of thing.
Being a feminist on the internet, I get that

913.text:
quite a lot, but that really doesn't bother
me very much. But for me it's when people

919.text:
around me, people who I'm very close to, say
things that are just cruel and unnecessary.

928.text:
I feel worthless and I just, I feel like I'm
being physically ripped apart until I'm nothing.

937.text:
I think the people close to me, certain people
close to me, have that power over me and I

941.text:
wish they didn't but I feel like every word
just tears me apart a little bit more. So

947.text:
I think the self harm in a way is like tearing
myself apart, it's like this misplaced anger

953.text:
and I want to aim anger at somebody else but
I can't and I aim it at myself instead and

958.text:
it's a punishment because I feel so useless
and worthless and it's just a very complicated

965.text:
situation. And these feelings have been inside
me for a very long time and there's no way

969.text:
they can get out and they never have been
able to get out. Maybe one day. Maybe one

974.text:
day I'll be able to express it properly, but
right now there's no one I can do that with…

976.text:
who's outside of it. But maybe one day that
will happen. I don't know.

985.text:
I think that if you're the same as me then
you might know what I'm talking about. I think

991.text:
you'll be able to relate to this so without
me actually talking about it properly I think

997.text:
you'll know. So you're not on your own and
I have been there and I am there right now

1003.text:
so don't worry and we can get through it.
Question number five is: Do You Cover Your

1009.text:
Scars And Have You Ever Covered Them?
At school I covered my arms. They were…

1013.text:
I had cuts up both of my forearms and on my
shoulders as well so I did used to wear long

1020.text:
sleeve t shirts all the time and like jumpers
and things, even when it was really hot. And

1025.text:
um, I remember, I was a performing arts student
and we had to do some dance rehearsals and

1031.text:
we were doing this rock and roll routine and
it was quite athletic, there were lots of

1035.text:
lifts and things, and I remember spending
this whole fifty minute lesson like trying

1041.text:
to keep my long sleeves down, like trying
to hold them down while dancing, and also

1047.text:
trying not to wince or make any sort of flinching,
no flinching movements when my partner and

1054.text:
other people in the dance would absolutely
brush my arms, that kind of thing, cause it

1057.text:
was painful. That was, that was quite difficult
for me and that entire question really sticks

1062.text:
in my head. I was in a very bad place then,
so I did used to cover them up, yes.

1066.text:
Now I don't bother to cover them up because
I, like I said before, I live at home and

1071.text:
I live with my mum and my brother and I don't
really go out very much so there's nobody

1078.text:
I need to hide them for. My family know I
do it. There's scars now, so they're used

1081.text:
to it I guess. I have bought some fingerless
gloves from ebay for the days when if I were

1088.text:
to relapse, you know, if they were fresh and
I wanted to hide them because the reaction

1093.text:
from my family when I do cut my arms is extremely
negative. I mean, ugh, I absolutely dread

1100.text:
my mum seeing them after I've done them. And
I try to hold that moment off as long as I

1105.text:
can so I cover them for a little while and
then in the end, you know, you think they've

1109.text:
faded a bit more, but, you know, she'll notice
when you're in the kitchen doing something,

1113.text:
then suddenly you're manipulative and twisted
and I don't know, selfish and that kind of

1119.text:
thing. And that stuff stays with you. So I
guess I still hide them if they're new now

1125.text:
but they're not often new now because I don't
do it anymore. Or I hardly ever do it anymore.

1130.text:
But I'm not ashamed of my scars. I'm not ashamed
of my scars. They just show that I've lived

1134.text:
through it and that I got though it, so in
a way I'm kind of proud of them.

1138.text:
The next question on my list is: In What Ways
Did You Self Harm?

1142.text:
The main way I self harmed was I used to cut
my forearms with a penknife and my shoulders

1146.text:
occasionally but not that often. I used to
restrict food so I wouldn't eat for about

1152.text:
three days until I felt like I was going to
pass out and then I would eventually eat.

1156.text:
I overexercised to get bruises. When I first
started hooping I was deliberately doing it

1164.text:
too much to try and bruise myself. That was
not good. And I didn't acknowledge that that

1168.text:
was self harm at the time. I felt like, I
didn't want to admit that to myself really,

1175.text:
but that was what I was doing. That was what
I was doing and it's not healthy so now obviously

1179.text:
I set myself time limits when I hoop and I
don't deliberately try and bruise myself when

1184.text:
I do that. I guess that's how deep the compulsion
lies in me. A couple of times I bashed my

1190.text:
head against the wall. I didn't do that very
much to be honest. It didn't do much for me.

1196.text:
I used to, I think this is more of a stress
reaction but I used to like peel the skin

1200.text:
off my lips. I'm sorry, that's really gross,
but I did used to kind of peel the skin of

1203.text:
my lips, so that was really stingy and it
hurt. And also I took too many tablets a few

1208.text:
times. Obviously when I overdosed I was aiming
for, you know, actually leaving, but before

1214.text:
that I used to take quite a few tablets at
a time. And I, I didn't have a plan and I

1219.text:
just, I just wanted to punish myself and I
thought if I died then I died and I didn't

1224.text:
care. So I guess that was a form of self harm
as well.

1227.text:
And finally, my last question is: What Advice
Do You Have For People Who Self Harm?

1232.text:
I really want you to know that self harming
does not make you a bad person and it doesn't

1235.text:
make you a weak person. It doesn't make you
manipulative and it doesn't make you selfish.

1239.text:
Okay? People will tell you those things, but
that's not what it is. You're just a person

1243.text:
that's in pain and you deserve to be cared
for and loved. It's like how animals if they're

1250.text:
caught in traps, they sometimes, they actually
gnaw off their own limbs to free themselves

1255.text:
and I think that's kind of what it's like.
I think that we're in such… we get into

1259.text:
such a bad place and we feel like there's
nothing that can be done and we don't know

1263.text:
what to do and we just take it out on ourselves,
we just punish ourselves cause we're in that

1266.text:
much pain. That's nothing to be ashamed of.
You know, if you're in that much pain then…

1273.text:
I just don't understand why people would put
you down when you're already in enough pain

1276.text:
that you're actually mutilating yourself.
But just please know that it doesn't make

1280.text:
you a weak person or a bad person at all.
It just means that you're a person who's going

1285.text:
through some troubles and needs some help.
I would advise you to see a professional definitely.

1289.text:
So maybe go and see a doctor or ring up a
local helpline. I'm not gonna make a list

1295.text:
of that because, you know, I've got viewers
from all over the place, but you can look

1299.text:
that up online. If you're watching this you've
got internet access, so look up your local

1303.text:
helplines. I really would advise, maybe if
there's someone close to you like a close

1307.text:
family member that you trust. If there's someone
you can talk to then utilise that, cause I

1313.text:
don't have that and I didn't have that, but
if I had then I think things would be different.

1318.text:
What I do have is I sometimes am able to ring
my grandma when I feel very low, she's said

1323.text:
to me I can ring her, so although I can't
talk about everything I do have an outlet

1328.text:
and I do have a person that I can go to if
things get very very extreme. So if there's

1333.text:
a person you can go to then that's always
a great idea.

1337.text:
Try the techniques I described if you can
and there's no guarantee that they'll work

1341.text:
but you might find one that works for you
just like I found one with drawing on my arm.

1345.text:
And also don't feel bad if you relapse. Relapsing
is a part of recovery. It doesn't mean that

1351.text:
you've failed. Recovery is a process that
goes on for a long time and it doesn't just

1355.text:
get… it's not easy, it doesn't just steadily
get better and better and better, you know,

1359.text:
you have some dips in the road but if you
stick with it you can get somewhere. You know,

1363.text:
there is a way to recover from it. You don't
have to be self harming all the time. I was

1367.text:
in a place where I was self harming every
single day and I don't self harm for months

1372.text:
on end now and i'm just getting better and
better so it is possible.

1375.text:
Please be kind to yourself. I know it's so
easy to, when you're in that state, to think

1379.text:
about all the bad things about yourself, like
every negative thing anyone's ever said about

1383.text:
you just pops into your head and it makes
you feel worthless but you have to try and

1387.text:
think about yourself as you'd think about
a friend so imagine if you had a friend who

1391.text:
was in the same situation, a friend that you
loved and admired and respected, you'd be

1395.text:
kind to them, wouldn't you? You'd give them
a hug and you'd give them some support. Give

1399.text:
yourself that same support if you can, you've
got to love yourself and know that you are

1403.text:
worth something and you're important and no
matter what anyone says to you, that doesn't

1408.text:
change. It doesn't change that at all. You're
still an important person. I get so angry

1412.text:
when people bring down others for showing
'weakness'. Self harm is not a weakness, in

1419.text:
fact if anything it's a strength. The fact
that you're still here and you feel that bad,

1424.text:
that is a strength and you're a strong person
and I respect and admire you and you can get

1428.text:
through this.
So that's the end of my video for today. I

1431.text:
know it's very long but I hope it was helpful.
There's gonna be lots of people, I know, in

1436.text:
the comments section, saying that they don't
think I should be talking about this kind

1440.text:
of thing, that I'm attention seeking and that
kind of thing, but I can tell you from the

1446.text:
heart, honestly, that when I was at my worst
I was hunting the internet for people talking

1450.text:
about their experiences so I wouldn't feel
alone. That's why I'm doing this. I know it

1453.text:
helps and if it helps one person then it's
absolutely worth it. I really really hope

1459.text:
that things get better for you. And I just
really love and respect and admire you, and

1465.text:
you can get through this. You're not a weak
person. You're a very important person, you're

1469.text:
a very strong person. And a lot of people,
a lot more people than you might think have

1474.text:
self harmed before or do self harm, it's just
that because of the stigma a lot of us keep

1479.text:
quiet, but there's a lot of us out there and
it doesn't make you any less of a person.

1483.text:
Kay, I'm gonna go now. I love you very much
and I'll see you soon. Bye. x
